bestBHT.bht: When John the Baptist caught sight of Jesus, he fixed his gaze upon Him, offering a significant hint for others to follow suit. This repetition signaled John's humility and centered people's attention on finding forgiveness of sins in Christ. It is in this instance that the small beginnings of the Church are apparent, as Christ begins to gather His followers. John's delight in beholding Jesus as the Lamb of God, who takes away the sin of the world, emphasizes the accessibility and assistance offered by Christ to those who desire to approach Him.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: looking—having fixed his eyes, with significant gaze, on Jesus.
To have done this once (see on :-) was humility enough [BENGEL].
The repetition of that wonderful proclamation, in identical terms and without another word, could only have been meant as a gentle hint to go after Him—as they did.
Albert Barnes: Fixing his eyes intently upon him. Singling him out and regarding him with special attention.
Contemplating him as the long-expected Messiah and Deliverer of the world.
In this way all ministers should fix the eye upon the Son of God, and direct all others to him.
John Calvin: Here we see also how small and low the beginning of the Church was. John, indeed, prepared disciples for Christ, but it is only now that Christ begins to collect a Church.
We ought also to observe what is the chief object to which John directs the attention of men; it is, to find in Christ the forgiveness of sins.

We ought not therefore to fear that Christ will withdraw from us or refuse to us easy access, provided that he sees us desirous to come to him; but, on the contrary, he will stretch out his hand to assist our endeavors.
Archibald T. Robertson: He looked (εμβλεψας). First aorist active participle of εμβλεπω, antecedent action before λεγε (says).

As he walked (περιπατουντ). Present active participle in dative case after εμβλεψας and like ερχομενον in verse John 1:29 vividly pictures the rapture of John in this vision of Jesus, so far as we know the third and last glimpse of Jesus by John (the baptism, verse John 1:29, and here).
Saith (λεγε). Historical present, change from ιστηκε before. He repeats part of the tribute in verse John 1:29.
John Gill: And looking upon Jesus as he walked... John fixed his eyes intently on Christ, with great pleasure and delight..."
The Lamb of God... taketh away the sin of the world

bhtAttempts.bht: As John the Baptist walked and saw Jesus, he fixed his eyes on Him, recognizing Him as the long-awaited Messiah. This repetition of proclamation was a gentle hint for others to follow Jesus. John's intense gaze portrayed his humility, and he directed the attention of men to find in Christ the forgiveness of sins. We should not fear approaching Jesus, for He will reach out His hand to assist our endeavors. This moment marks the small beginnings of the Church, as Christ begins to collect His followers. John's delight in beholding Jesus highlights the significance of Jesus as the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world.

John the Baptist looked intently at Jesus as he walked, fixing his eyes on Him in recognition of the Messiah. The repetition of this proclamation was a gentle hint for others to follow Jesus. John's gaze reflected his humility and directed people to find forgiveness of sins in Christ. We shouldn't fear approaching Jesus, for He will reach out to assist us. This moment marks the small beginnings of the Church, as Christ begins to gather His followers. John delighted in beholding Jesus as the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world.

As John the Baptist walked, he fixed his eyes on Jesus with a significant gaze, repeating the proclamation about Him as a gentle hint for others to follow. John's intense and humble gaze directed people to find forgiveness of sins in Christ. This marked the beginning of the Church as Christ gathered followers, and John delighted in beholding Jesus as the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world. We need not fear approaching Jesus, for He will reach out and assist our endeavors to come to Him.

When John the Baptist caught sight of Jesus, he fixed his gaze upon Him, offering a significant hint for others to follow suit. This repetition signaled John's humility and centered people's attention on finding forgiveness of sins in Christ. It is in this instance that the small beginnings of the Church are apparent, as Christ begins to gather His followers. John's delight in beholding Jesus as the Lamb of God, who takes away the sin of the world, emphasizes the accessibility and assistance offered by Christ to those who desire to approach Him.

As John the Baptist walked, he fixed his eyes on Jesus with a significant gaze, silently directing others to follow. This humble act emphasized the importance of finding forgiveness of sins in Christ. It marked the beginning of the Church as Christ gathered His followers, and John delighted in beholding Jesus as the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world. We need not fear approaching Jesus, for He will stretch out His hand to assist our endeavors.
